paper.title: Anatomy of banking crises in developing and emerging market countries
paper.abstract: This paper uses a Binary Classification Tree (BCT) model to analyze banking crises in 50 emerging market and developing countries during 1990-2005. The BCT model identifies three conditions (and the specific threshold of the key indictors) at which the vulnerability to banking crisis increases (i) very high inflation, (ii) highly dollarized bank deposits combined with nominal depreciation or low bank liquidity, and (iii) low bank profitability which highlight that foreign currency risk, poor financial soundness, and macroeconomic instability are important drivers of banking crises. The results also emphasize the importance of conditional thresholds in triggering crises, in that banking crises are underlined by a combination of vulnerabilities or a sequence of (non-linear) conditions rather than the deterioration of a unique factor. domain_result.justification: The paper focuses on analyzing banking crises using a Binary Classification Tree model to identify key indicators and thresholds that increase vulnerability to such crises. This research is directly related to understanding and managing systemic financial risks, which falls under the domain of Financial Risk Management.
